header.title: Is It Better To Have Young or Old Parents?
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Whatever you need a website for, create yours today with Wix: https://www.wix.com/go/infographics . When people are deciding what age to have children at, you'll often hear them say that before they have kids there are a lot of things they want to get done first. Maybe travel the world, maybe concentrate on a career, or at least just wait until the twenties are out of the way. On the flip side, some people will tell you that they want to have children at a young enough age so that they can actively play sports with their children when the kids are in their teens, adding that they don't want to be ageing parents because they fear they won't have the energy required, say, in their 50s, to still be dealing with kids. Today we'll talk about all the pros and cons, in this episode of the Infographics Show, Is it better to be born to younger or older parents?. . . SUBSCRIBE TO US -► http://bit.ly/TheInfographicsShow. . --------------------------------------------------------------------------. . WEBSITE (SUGGEST A TOPIC):. http://theinfographicsshow.com . . Younger. How useful can an 80 year old grandparent be? 1:30 while the woman's age is a factor, the man' s age is as well. Specifically, the risk of having a child with achondroplasia—a type of dwarfism—spikes from 1 in 15,000 to 1 in 1,923 once men rea ch age 50. And the risk of schizophrenia more than quadrupled, from 1 in 100 within the general population to 1 in 22 with fathers over 50. What's more, autism rates rise from 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 174 for kids whose dads had them af ter age 40. Unfortunately, cancer rates among offspring also seem to rise too as their dads grow older, possibly because of some of the same DNA mutations that contribute to other conditions. For example, a woman's lifetime risk of breast cancer typically stands at 1 in 8, but rises to 1 in 5.3 if her dad was 40 or older when she was born, according to the same Baylor review. And childhood leukemia strikes 1 in 36,000 kids in the general population, but 1 in 21,302 of those with fat hers age 40-plus.

I think it can go either way. Young parents can be financially responsible and ready and some older parents can be the opposite. For example, I got married at age 21 because we wanted too and had been in a relationship for a long time. Our first child was born when I was almost 23. No drugs, no drinking, we had our finances mostly stable. We weren't extremely well off, but were both debt free and knew how to budget and maintain our household. A few years later we had our twins and were much more financially well off. Our kids are well adjusted and , so far, do well in school and don't have any behavioral issues or anything. But, there's a mom who has a child in my son's class and she had him at 43, unplanned, and has a history of drug and alcohol abuse. She still lives with her parents and can't maintain a job as well as relies on her mom to do most of the parenting for her. Her son is always in trouble, got kicked out of preschool. Has been reprimanded several times for bullying and even cursing at the teachers and had to be held back for the next school year because his classroom performance wasn't at a level that would make the next grade an easy adjustment for him. But, there are older parents that fit the mold you mentioned and young parents that do as well. There will always be exceptions, but generalizing may not be the best approach.

Based on my experience, young parents.

My parents had me at 40 and 43. My mom got married 3 yrs before I was born. When I told a high school friend that, he told me that I was a miracle. One time early in high school, a couple of friends were talking about their dads reaching 50 and I told them mine was reaching 60. They didn't have much energy to play with me as a kid (they got tired easily, but I was able to entertain myself and I was able to get over lack of playing time). They're in their late 60s, with my dad turning 70 in a few months. I'm in my mid-20s and I've been taking care of my mom for the last several yrs (my parents are divorced and I'm her lone caregiver). Being a caregiver in your 20s is NOT FUN. At all. I'm stuck in the nest while all my friends from high school and college have jobs, spouses, and (in some cases) kids. And most of the people I was with in high school aren't in my hometown anymore. I'm hoping I'm not unemployable and forever single. Contrary to media outlets, people in my generation (millennials) are getting married early. I know A LOT of people from high school and college who've gotten married in the last 5-6 yrs.

However, I do thank the Lord that my circumstances aren't worse and that I'm able to hold it together. And last year, I knew 8 people (11 overall when siblings are included) who lost a parent last year. 7 were from high school, 1 from college. Of them all, most of them were in their 50s when they died. Two were in their 60s, with the oldest being 65.

If you wait until your late 30s/early 40s to have kids, your kids are at risk of taking care of you much sooner than expected. It's a disadvantage that needs to be made more public. It's better to have your kids take care of you AFTER they get their lives/careers launched and not BEFORE. People label it as selfishness, but to me, you're being careless if you have kids at 40. Barring unforeseen circumstances, have your kids while you're young. DO NOT be a teen parent, but don't wait too long. Rather than tell someone who says don't wait to mind their business, listen to them, especially if their premise is based on keeping your kids from spending their 20s taking care of you.

Should I be childless (and married) by the time I reach 40, I'm adopting, if circumstances allow it. In that scenario, I'm adopting a child that would've been by biological child in my early to mid 30s.

As far as some of the points mentioned:

-Barring something unforeseen, my mom will live a long life, but it's not going to be because she had me late. For her, it'll be because of genetics. My great-grandmother lived to be 94 (her last surviving sister lived to be 100) and my grandmother will soon turn 91. Those two were young when they had kids.

-Most of my older relatives are still alive. Few have died. My family is relatively big.

-And as far as kids helping older parents with tech issues, it's likely annoying and cringeworthy from the kid's perspective. I'm basing that on my personal experiences.

commentThread.commentText: I worked in schools and childcare centres for years. 9/10, older parents were better. There were, of course, some good young parents, but the vast majority of the time the older  parents were better parents - less selfish, more mature, more focused on the kids, more stable relationships etc. Additionally, parents who chose to have only one child tended to be the best (and least stressed) parents, because they were completely focused on that child, as opposed to having to divide their attention between multiple children. Overall, I have been fully convinced that waiting longer to have children is always a good idea - and so is limiting the number of children that you have.

Obviously I don't know any other way, but my parents are older and I really appreciate the years of experience and wisdom they have. I think this has made them good parents, and better parents than they would have been when they were younger. Growing up, they seemed to  find a great balance between letting us be independent and having rules/ "managing" us. They almost always handle things in a calm and balanced way. Of course they aren't perfect, but I personally wouldn't wish for younger parents.

commentThread.commentText: I find the parents of my friends who are considered as younger parents to be cringy. They act like they're still cool.

Grew up with a younger set of parents, and they did not have the financial abilities to get pregnant with a couple of kids in their teens. One of my parents had to work hardcore just to get our families head above water and i rarely got to see them, and the other parent doesn't know how to emotionally handle kids and is emotionally stuck at the age us kids came around. So much so the one parent became emotionally volitile and not able to care for me or my siblings-we ended up having to parent the one parent at times. Not saying all younger parents are destined to become this way, I live in a poor area so ofc I know many young parents and it's a mixed bag of some very bad parents and some amazing hardworking ones. But I always felt jealous over those with older parents, like all my friends have. They always complain that their parents don't understand them due to the generational gap (granted, my parents are considered millenials and I'm on the cusp of millenial and gen z generation, so there's not much generational misunderstanding-albeit theres no generation gap with others in my family since we're all poor and in the same boat. They understand hardships much better and can sympathize) but I still felt that the way their parents handled situations were more mature, and some of my friends are a little spoiled (doesnt make them bad people though <3). Sometimes when I watch their fights happen it's the friend and parent misinterpretting each other and the friend might be acting out of selfish though-or rather, not really thinking about what the parent is feeling, and vice versa. Also their fights are never life and death, while growing up with younger parents I've had one particular parent act in rage and threaten to kill or beat me. There's not a lot of benefits to be born with very young parents, and I personally never intend to become one myself. I hope that every person who becomes a parent-either by surprise or planned out-can watch helpful videos, read books, and receive education to help themselves grow into the best parent they can be.

My dad had me 6 months shy of turning 60 and my mom was 35 at the time. While growing up I was always embarrassed to be the only one with an older dad (everyone thought he was my grandpa). He had a big car accident when I was 3 so I only remember him as being handicaped. I've never seen him run, play with us, do sports etc. We did have a lot more than others financially but he retired when I was 10 and it also sucked to always have my parents at home all the time. Growing up we always had to put up with his health issues. He became forgetful, incontinent etc. He passed away suddenly (stroke) at age 83 (I was a 24 year old student, doing my masters degree). When I was young I always swore that I'd be a young mother and that I'd have my kids b y age 25. I'm now 36, married with two little kids that I had at age 32 and 35. I definitely don't see myself as an 'old mom' since all my friends have kids more or less the same age. Back when I was young mothers were younger but not anymore. Hey, I really don't understand how you guys did the research for the health risks associated with pregnancy and age related to women, and somehow still chose to omit the fact the the health risks for both mother and child are significantly higher, in terms of both mortality and morbidity rates, when the mother is younger than 21. This is supported by both the CDC and the WHO who ran massive meta studies showing that it was biological immaturity rather than other factors which increased the risk. Having a child younger than 21 was shown to be far more risky than having one older than 35, and the increased risks associated with having a child with developmental disabilities also is largely dependent on the age of the man th e woman is with. Men over t he age of 31 have a notable decrease in sperm quality, and as women tend to partner with men in a 5 year window of of their own age (2 years younger, to 3 years older) their male partner's adva nced age contributes to those issues. However, when speaking about developmental disabilities of children born to older mothers, people will often cite the fact that those risks double afte r the age of 35, but neglect to mention that that doubling is off of a risk factor of less than 1%, and the doubled number is still under 1%, meaning that the added benefits of waiting for the opportune time to have a child for some couples would still greatly outweigh the likelihood of such defects. It's around the same probability of dying while getting your wisdom teeth out, so people pushing that narrative so much seems far more about trying to dictate when couples (particularly women) should have kids, rather than being based on hard facts and logic. When it comes to women, the best time to have a child from a purely biological stand point, based on the best data we have that accounts for wealth, and environment, is 21-31, with a decline after 35. Men do not in fact "keep giving and giving", there is also a reduction in sperm quality following the same time frames.

commentThread.commentText: What are parents?

I thought this was going to look from the perspective of the child, but it turns out it is from the perspective of the parents. There is one important factor not mentioned here. Children born to older parents are more likely to have to become a full time carer to their parents when their parents degrading health takes away their independence (unless the option of a care home is available, at great expense). This will likely happen right at the time when the child is reaching the peak of their career in middle age, and have a family of their own to raise, forcing them to give it all up to be a carer for possibly 20+ years. If the parents are young, the offspring will likely be approaching or in retirement by the time they have to do the full time carer role, meaning that have had the chance to fully live their life and do the best they can.

Some downsides are that we don't ever go out for lunch or dinner because they don't like leaving the house, technology skills are not great, the generation gap (cultural differences in my mum's case) sometimes makes it difficult for them to understand me.

I guess my opinion would be there are positives and negatives to both older and younger parents, but I think the most important thing is to have loving, supportive and capable parents which is possible in both scenarios.
